data.title: Test: run task in terminal instead of output window
data.body:
Refs: #18312
Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows @roblourens
- [x] Linux @aeschli 
- [x] Mac @Tyriar 

Tasks can now be executed in the terminal instead of the `Output` window. To enable this you need to add a global property `"_runner": "terminal"` to the tasks.json file.

Executing a task in a terminal should work as executing a task in the output windows including problem matcher, watching task (now named background tasks) and commands per task. When a task is executed in  the terminal you get the additional features:

- output encoding plus full ANSI character support (comes for free from the terminal)
- input (the task can read from stdin)  (comes for free from the terminal)
- you can run more than one task in parallel.
- control over the shell to be used.

Please test that all the features available in the 'output' runner work in the 'terminal' runner plus the newly mentioned features. Try to kill a n active task F1 > task terminate. The terminal runner tries to reuse terminals. Ensure that the reuse strategy makes sense. Play a little with task executed in the terminal. If you have ideas, please let me know. Executing them in the terminal opens new use cases. 

Please also note that due to a problem in the terminal command quoting when executed in a shell doesn't work as expected. So a command like `"dir "folder with spaces""` is not correctly executed in a cmd.exe run in the terminal. See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19078 for details: 

Here is a sample tasks.json to start with:

```json
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "_runner": "terminal",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "tsc",
            "command": "tsc -w",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "isBackground": true,
            "problemMatcher": "$tsc-watch",
        },
        {
            "taskName": "dir",
            "command": "dir",
            "windows": {
                "isShellCommand": {
                    "executable": "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe",
                    "args": ["/d", "/c"]
                }
            }
        } 
    ]
}
```

The first task executes the tsc compiler in watch mode (assumes it is available globally). The second one executes the dir command using a special shell path for the terminal.

data.title: vscode-insiders embed terminal behavior since 1.9.0
data.body:
Hi!

I've an issue with latest update.

```
Version 1.9.0-insider
Commit 882244ea24cb0b89a9a0c6c649c8f857fb0bc408
Date 2017-01-23T07:03:07.900Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0
```

OS: Debian 8

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch `vim` in the embed terminal

Used to work before `1.9.0`. Now I can't do my `git commit` command anymore because it does open the `$EDITOR`. 

Nano, less etc. are still working. Therefore, I think it has to do with my vim configuration. What are recent changes that could affect this? Note that `vi` prints black on black.

Test for #18147

**Instructions**

When clicking the language switcher in the status bar, there will be an option to search the Marketplace for more extensions for `*.foo` files. Make sure the contents make sense for the given file extension.

data.title: Test: Git as an SCM extension
data.body:
Test for #18615, #15246
Complexity 4

- [x] Windows - @ramya-rao-a 
- [x] OS X - @sandy081 
- [x] Linux - @roblourens 

**Test Steps**

There has been an exploration towards having SCM providers in VS Code. Git is halfway implemented on top of it. In order to test it, you must run the `SCM: Enable Preview SCM` global command.

Before filing for missing features, refer to #18615, where most of those are tracked.

- Test that the `SCM: Enable Preview SCM` and `SCM: Disable Preview SCM` work as advertised: they should toggle between having the classic git UI to having the new SCM viewlet
- Test that when Preview SCM is disabled, git works just as before
- With Preview SCM enabled:
  - Test that the viewlet's contents always match what `git status` would show
  - Test the diff editor which opens upon click of the viewlet's items
  - Test that there are still dirty diff decorations in the gutter margin of the editor
  - Test staging, undoing and unstaging commands/actions
  - Test commit command
  - Test sync, pull, push & publish commands
  - Test that merge conflict decorations appear highlighted
  - Test that you can checkout branches using the status bar & global command
  - Test that you can create branches using the global command
  - Test the viewlet menu actions as well as context actions
  - Test that the git output channel's content makes sense
  - Test that there's a `git fetch` every now and then (check the git output)

- [x] @bpasero  

re #16911 

Test that we now also ask for code actions on just words. Previously we would ask for code actions only on errors and warnings. Make sure that

* we only ask once per squiggle and that squiggles that precedence

data.title: test inserting snippet via keybinding
data.body:
- [x] @rebornix 
- [x] @mjbvz 


re #17780

We can now insert a snippet by just  pressing a key combination. Test that the `insertSnippet` command can be configured in `keybindings.json` with argument which can be the following:

1. `snippet: foo$0bar` such that the argument itself defines the snippet
2. `name: someName` such that is references an existing snippet by name
3. `name: someName, langId: someLangId` to reference an existing snippet from a different language.

A sample would be
```json
{
  "key": "cmd+k '",
  "command": "editor.action.insertSnippet",
  "args": {
    "name": "in quotes" // name of a snippet defined by an extension or user
  }
},
```

data.title: Test: multiple commands in tasks.json
data.body:
Refs: #981
Complexity: 2

- [x] @weinand 
- [x] @aeschli 

The tasks.json now support to specify a command per task. The following properties can be specified:

command: string - the command to execute
isShellCommand: boolean - whether the command is a shell command
args: string[] - arguments passed to the command.
options: { cwd: string, env: any } - spawn options

Test the following:

- that a task can take these arguments
- that there are OS specific overrides per task (windows, osx, linux)
- that the merging rule make sense and are correct. They should behave like this. `command` and `isShellCommand` are overriding, arguments are concatenated, options.cwd is overriding and options.env are merged.

And example is:
```json
        {
            "taskName": "node",
            "command": "node",
            "linux": {
                "command": "/usr/bin/node"
            },
            "args": [
                "helloWorld.js"
            ]
        }
```

Commands can still be defined globally and globally per OS. If a command is defined globally and per task (`command`, `isShellCommand` or `options` property set) the definition setting the command property wins without merging `isShellCommand`, `options` or `args` properties. This is done to keep the overall command definition as local as possible.

Instead of testing this per task augmenting the `src\vs\workbench\parts\tasks\test\node\configuration.test.ts` is also a possibility.

data.title: Test: support to launch an adapter through an extension
data.body:
Test for #8645:
Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows - @bpasero  
- [x] Linux - @roblourens

Previously VS Code has launched a debug adapter by using the (static) attributes `program`,  `args`, `runtime` and `runtimeArgs` from the package.json of the corresponding extension.
With this milestone this information can be dynamically calculated by a command implemented in an extension.

To verify:
- check out any debug extension, e.g. vscode-node-debug
- remove the attributes `program`,  `args`, `runtime` and `runtimeArgs` from the package.json (not all are used in all extensions)
- set a new attribute `adapterExecutableCommand` to an ID of a command that is registered in the extension.
- make this command return a structure with this format:
  ```json
  command: "<executable>",
  args: [ "<argument1>", "<argument2>", ... ]
  ```
The attribute "command" must be a either an absolute path to an executable or a name of executable looked up via the PATH environment variable. The special value`node` will be mapped to VS Code's built-in node runtime without being looked up on the PATH.

Verify that VS Code shows appropriate error messages when the command is invalid.

data.title: Test: support for internal modules in 'skip files' option
data.body:
Test for #16918 and #18396:
Complexity: 2

- [x] Windows - @egamma 
- [x] OS X - @joaomoreno
- [x] Linux - @mjbvz 

It is now possible to use the 'magic name' `<node_internals>` for specifying internal node modules in glob patterns used for the `skip_files` attribute. For details of the `skip_files` attribute see https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/node-debugging#_skipping-uninteresting-code.

Verify that `<node_internals>` works as expected and that internal modules are shown in dimmed mode in the CALL STACK view and that the hover explains why they are dimmed.

Please try this with both 'node' and 'node2'.

data.title: Find for whole project -> All folders
data.body:
I have seen one extension for finding in the current folder.  A global find, that searches all folders in your current project, would be extremely useful.

Thanks.

data.title: Test: 'restart' option for 'launch' requests
data.body:
Test for #17381:
Complexity: 2

- [x] Windows - @dbaeumer 
- [x] OS X - @joaomoreno
- [x] Linux - @alexandrudima 

For quite some time the VS Code node debugger supported a 'restart' attribute on 'attach' configurations. See https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/node-debugging#_attaching-to-nodejs for details.
With this release we now support the 'restart' attribute on 'launch' configurations as well.
If this feature is enabled, VS Code will restart a debug session whenever it detects the termination of node.js.

An example for how to verify this feature uses nodemon and the following test program `app.js`:
```js
let i = 0;

setInterval(() => {
	console.log('hello:' + i++);
}, 1000);
```
In your launch config you can use Intellisense snippets to create a  'Nodemon setup' launch config.
After launching this you can edit `app.js` and VS Code should restart the debug session automatically.

Try to verify another scenario that uses 'restart' in a 'launch' configuration.

data.title: Test: launch configuration snippets
data.body:
Test for #18776:
Complexity: 3 

- [x] Windows - @Tyriar 
- [x] OS X or Linux-  @bpasero 

We've added these launch config snippets for common node.js based scenarios: 
- (launch with nodemon)
- attach to a process (use picker)
- debug mocha tests
- launch with 'npm debug'
- Debugging the yeoman generator
- debug gulp tasks
 
Verify all but the first snippet (the 'nodemon' snippet is covered by #19040). The generated launch config and editing it in snippet mode should make sense and launching a debug session should work.

data.body:
1. open command prompt `code-insiders`
2. No folder workspace is opened and there is the welcome experience

In this case we should not show the welcome experience, we are an editor the user just wanted to edit a new untitiled file, welcome experience is not needed in this case.

Another strange scenario
1. Open new window
2. An no folder workspace is opened and there is the welcome experience

We should only show the welcome experience for the folder workspace
fyi @bpasero

data.title: Add API to find out if an extension is being debugged or not
data.body:
An extension can find out if it runs in debug mode by analysing the arguments passed to node:
```js
const debug = process.execArgv.filter(v => v.indexOf('--debug') === 0).length > 0;
```

It would be nice to have a real API for this. 

/cc @dbaeumer @daviwil @jrieken

data.title: Test: 'Add configuration' debug select dropdown
data.body:
- [x] @jrieken 
- [x] @ramya-rao-a 

Complexity: 1

We have added a 'Add configuration' option in the debug select drop down in the debug viewlet. Verify:
* Clicking on this options opens launch.json and triggers intelli-sens so you can easily add a new launch configuration. VSCode will ask for the environment first if it can not auto detect it (namely will not ask if you have a .js file open)
* You can do this even if there is no launch.json

data.title: January Endgame
data.body:
## Endgame Schedule
- *January 23* Code freeze for the endgame
- *Febuary 1* Endgame done

### Endgame Week

#### Monday, January 23
- [x] Code freeze at 2am CET / 5pm PT
- [x] All test items contain sufficiently comprehensive test descriptions by 3am CET / 6pm PT
- [x] Ensure we have a green build on all platforms

#### Tuesday, January 24
- [x] Test build starts at 7am CET / 10pm PT Monday
- [x] Test plan ready by 8am CET / 11pm PT Monday
- [x] Testing

#### Wednesday, January 25
- [x] Morning issue triage
- [x] Testing, Fixing
- [x] [Verification](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Issue-Tracking#verification) Since there are quite some old bugs to verify we verify by age, youngest first. The queries are:
  - [Verification needed](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aissue+-label%3Averified+is%3Aclosed+label%3Averification-needed)
  - [Issues To Verify](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3Abug+-label%3Averified+is%3Aclosed+-label%3Aduplicate+-label%3Ainvalid+-label%3Aas-designed+milestone%3A%22January+2017%22)

#### Thursday, January 26
- [x] Fixing last issues
- [x] Verification
- [x] Add/update shrink-wrap files for built-in extensions if needed (see [instructions](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8570#issuecomment-229669456))  - **endgame master**
- [x] Run [OSS tool](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-distro/blob/master/distro-tools/README.md) after merging shrink-wrap findings - **endgame master**
  - *The LCA review of the ThirdPartyNotices.txt files is not needed anymore*
- [x] Check new OSS usage is entered into the [OSS registry](https://ossmsft.visualstudio.com/_apps/hub/ms.vss-oss-web.hub-oss) - **endgame master**

#### Friday, January 27
- [x] [Acknowledge Pull Requests](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tools/tree/master/thankyou) in release notes. - **endgame master**
- [x] Satellite modules/npm packages ready, version updated, smoke tested, [PRs acknowledged](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tools/tree/master/thankyou)
  - [x] [vscode](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-vscode) **@bpasero**
  - [x] [vscode-generator-code](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-generator-code) **@aeschli**
  - [x] [vsce](https://github.com/Microsoft/vsce) **@joaomoreno**
  - [x] [node debug](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug) **@weinand**
- [x] Translation input - **@dbaeumer**
- [x] [Smoketest](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Smoke-Test)
  - [x] Windows - @dbaeumer 
  - [x] OS X - @sandy081 
  - [x] Linux - @joaomoreno
- [x] Update the [Release Notes](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/blob/vnext/release-notes/) (including **notable fixes**) and [documentation](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/tree/vnext/docs).
  - [x] @alexandrudima
  - [x] @weinand
  - [x] @chrmarti

- [x] Freeze `insider` builds - **endgame master**

- [x] Bump up the version in `package.json` - **endgame master**

### Stabilisation Week: Jan 30 to Feb 3

#### Preparation

data.title: Use named pipes to talk to extension host
data.body: This PR helps with #18682 and other IPC scenarios as it improved the existing mechanism to communicate via named pipes and makes the extension host used that instead of process.send

data.title: Go to File includes files that are excluded by files.exclude/search.exclude
data.body:
My build process compiles files to public/*.html, and i'm trying to exclude the compiled files from search and Go to File.

My workspace settings looks like this:

```json
{
    "search.exclude": {
        "**/.git": true,
        "**/node_modules": true,
        "**/public": true,
        "**/bower_components": true
    },

    "files.exclude": {
        "**/public": true
    }
}
```

The settings seems to be applied to search and file explorer, but it's still appearing in the Go to File results.

I can't find any option in the default config that applies specifically to the Go to File results.

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OSX Sierra 10.12.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Apply the settings above to your workspace
2. Create a couple `.html` files in a folder called `public`
